(45) 304.26th November, 1945.CABINET.CO-ORDINATION OF MIDDLE EAST POLICY IN LONDON.Note by the Secretary of the Cabinet.AT their meeting on the 4th October, 1945 (CM. (45) 38th Conclusions,Item 6), the Cabinet approved, subject to a number of points which arose in discussion, the recommendations on Middle East policy and on the machinery required to give effect to that policy which were put forward by the foreign secretary in CP. (45) 174, following on the meeting of the Conference of BritishMiddle East Representatives which met in London in September 1945.2. Officials of the Departments primarily concerned have discussed themachinery required in London to give effect to the Cabinet's conclusions; andafter considering their recommendations the Prime Minister has approved thearrangements set out below for the establishment of the two Middle East Com-mittees and the Middle East Secretariat: (a) Middle East (Ministerial) Committee.Composition -Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Chairman).Chancellor of the Exchequer (with the Financial Secretary to theTreasury deputising for him as necessary).Secretary of State for the Colonies.Secretary of State for War.Secretary, Department of Overseas Trade.Arrangements will be made for other Ministers to receive the documents ofthe Committee, and be brought into consultation, when matters of concern to the mare under discussion.Terms of Reference.To consider such major questions of policy in respect of the Middle East asmay be referred to it.(b) Middle East (Official) Committee.C omposition 'Sir Kinahan Cornwallis (Chairman).Representatives of:Treasury.Foreign Office.Colonial Office.War Office.India Office.Board of Trade.Ministry of War Transport.Ministry of Food.Ministry of Supply.[30945] Terms of Reference. ,..To keep under review, in conformity with the requirements of ImperialSecurity, the general political, economic and supply policy of His Majesty'sGovernment as regards the Middle East and to co-ordinate departmental action as may be necessary. *(c) Middle East Secretariat.Functions.The Secretariat will (a) provide the Secretariat to the Middle East Ministerial and OfficialCommittees;(b) provide the Secretariat of any temporary or ad hoc committees or working parties within its field;(c) be the sole channel for receipt and despatch of cables and other com-municatiohs between London and the British Middle East Office and(on Middle East Office business) between London and Washington;(d) assist responsible Departments which seek help in connection with matters within the scope of the British Middle East Office, and wheremore than one Department is concerned and no Department isprepared to accept sole responsibility, to initiate action so as to obtainnecessary decisions;(e) generally keep the British Middle East Office informed of developments and trends affecting it, especially in connection with American plans,and with the activities of international agencies as they impinge onthe Middle East;(/) sponsor the claims of the British Middle East Office for assistance, forinstance, in the provision of experts; and(g) during the existence of the British Supply Mission, Middle East, fulfil the same tasks on its behalf.Composition.The Middle East Committees will be served by Joint Secretaries, providedby the Foreign Office and the Cabinet Office. The Secretary nominated by theCabinet Office will be primarily concerned with the meetings of the two committees. The Secretary nominated by the Foreign Office will, with theassistance of appropriate subordinate staff, carry on from the Foreign Office theday-to-day work of the Secretariat.(Signed) E. E. BRIDGES.Cabinet Offices, S.W. 1,2Qth November, 1945.
